{"title":[{"type":"heading1","text":"The 9 most important lessons from my first year at¬†Ueno","spans":[]}],"short_description":[{"type":"paragraph","text":"Last September, I started my first full-time job as a product designer at Ueno. I had applied online and did a brief trial period where I worked with Ueno for three days.","spans":[]}],"publication_date":"2017-10-17","author":{"id":"WcuwBikAADBphmkR","type":"author","tags":[],"slug":"steph-jeong","lang":"en-us","link_type":"Document","isBroken":false},"image":{"dimensions":{"width":704,"height":704},"alt":null,"copyright":null,"url":"https://ueno-starter-kit-universally-test.cdn.prismic.io/ueno-starter-kit-universally-test/d33e20942bfd8a4586d9694b727ec06e9244b5f2_1.jpg"},"body":[{"slice_type":"text","slice_label":null,"items":[{}],"primary":{"text":[{"type":"paragraph","text":"Last September, I started my first full-time job as a product designer at Ueno. I had applied online and did a brief trial period where I worked with Ueno for three days. There, I met¬†my future mentor Carolyn. I guess she thought I was okay, but she probably hired me for my amazing but mostly dumb tweet:","spans":[{"start":184,"end":208,"type":"hyperlink","data":{"link_type":"Web","url":"https://medium.com/ueno/building-a-culture-of-mentorship-c92032e03d59"}}]}]}},{"slice_type":"tweets","slice_label":null,"items":[{"tweet":{"url":"https://twitter.com/jeongsteph/status/572284330271232000","author_name":"Steph Jeong","author_url":"https://twitter.com/jeongsteph","html":"

I just realized a dog is called a dog because the word looks like a dog!!! üê©üê©

— Steph Jeong (@jeongsteph) March 2, 2015
\n","width":550,"height":null,"type":"rich","cache_age":"3153600000","provider_name":"Twitter","provider_url":"https://twitter.com","version":"1.0","embed_url":"https://twitter.com/jeongsteph/status/572284330271232000","title":"Steph Jeong on Twitter: \"I just realized a dog is called a dog because the word looks like a dog!!! üê©üê©\""}}],"primary":{}},{"slice_type":"text","slice_label":null,"items":[{}],"primary":{"text":[{"type":"paragraph","text":"I actually had no idea what I was looking for in a job. And, looking back, I probably had no idea what being a designer at Ueno even meant. But after the trial period, I accepted my offer because everyone on the team was better than me, and at least I could learn by watching them.","spans":[]},{"type":"paragraph","text":"And I was right. For the first three months, I had to constantly play catch-up and improve my craft, from sharpening my attention to detail to flexing my higher-level problem-solving skills. The months after that were even harder, because I had to master the soft skills that you‚Äôre not taught in school. Obviously, I still have a long way to go, but I‚Äôll share some I‚Äôve learned so far.","spans":[]},{"type":"heading3","text":"1. Be more than empathetic. Make¬†friends.","spans":[]}]}},{"slice_type":"image","slice_label":null,"items":[{}],"primary":{"image":{"dimensions":{"width":800,"height":323},"alt":null,"copyright":null,"url":"https://ueno-starter-kit-universally-test.cdn.prismic.io/ueno-starter-kit-universally-test/72e46aacbe5575fde1e0e2435f86aba7344cf190_s1.png","dfds":{"dimensions":{"width":500,"height":500},"alt":null,"copyright":null,"url":"https://ueno-starter-kit-universally-test.cdn.prismic.io/ueno-starter-kit-universally-test/6bdab1c2c31deeeb8d9f3f9618267018749d7324_s1.png"}},"caption":[{"type":"paragraph","text":"By Ketnipz","spans":[{"start":3,"end":10,"type":"hyperlink","data":{"link_type":"Web","url":"https://www.instagram.com/ketnipz/?hl=en"}}]}]}},{"slice_type":"text","slice_label":null,"items":[{}],"primary":{"text":[{"type":"paragraph","text":"Empathy~~~! (*jazz hands*) It‚Äôs a word so overused in design that it‚Äôs practically lost its meaning, but it‚Äôs critical to a project‚Äôs success. Designers usually talk about empathy with users, but being empathetic with your teammates and clients is equally important. How can you work well with them if you don‚Äôt understand them?","spans":[{"start":13,"end":25,"type":"em"}]},{"type":"paragraph","text":"The first time I worked with a client on my own, I struggled. A lot. I became defensive about my design decisions, felt misunderstood and underestimated, and was frustrated all the time. The work suffered because of it. So I asked for advice from our resident client-whisperer,¬†Luisa. She had an amazing personality, but that wasn‚Äôt the only reason why everyone loved her.","spans":[{"start":278,"end":283,"type":"hyperlink","data":{"link_type":"Web","url":"https://twitter.com/luisamf"}}]},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Her magic was simple: everyone likes working with nice people, but when you treat the people you work with as¬†friends, everything just gets easier. Get to know them, their stories, their hobbies‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand share more about yourself too. You‚Äôll be less likely to argue, more open-minded to each others‚Äô ideas, and you‚Äôll both understand that you want the best outcome for the project and for each other. And with that, you‚Äôll develop the trust needed for a great working relationship.","spans":[{"start":110,"end":117,"type":"em"}]},{"type":"paragraph","text":"This doesn‚Äôt just apply to clients, but to coworkers too. A homebody like me doesn‚Äôt dread going into the office on Monday, because I truly love the people I work with. We come from all over the world, and it‚Äôs sometimes difficult to understand everyone‚Äôs different perspectives and backgrounds. So we make sure to take the time to learn about each other and understand where people are coming from. We share our work problems, our life problems, and our dumb jokes. We know when to provide more support and when to be more critical with each other. Sure, we‚Äôll still disagree sometimes, but we know people are always coming from a good place because we care about each other.","spans":[]},{"type":"heading3","text":"2. Talking more doesn‚Äôt give you more authority. Listening well¬†can.","spans":[]}]}},{"slice_type":"image","slice_label":null,"items":[{}],"primary":{"image":{"dimensions":{"width":300,"height":169},"alt":null,"copyright":null,"url":"https://ueno-starter-kit-universally-test.cdn.prismic.io/ueno-starter-kit-universally-test%2Fa98d81cc-cb69-4cb4-847b-aad067e2ff74_s2.gif","dfds":{"dimensions":{"width":500,"height":500},"alt":null,"copyright":null,"url":"https://ueno-starter-kit-universally-test.cdn.prismic.io/ueno-starter-kit-universally-test%2Fa98d81cc-cb69-4cb4-847b-aad067e2ff74_s2.gif"}},"caption":[]}},{"slice_type":"text","slice_label":null,"items":[{}],"primary":{"text":[{"type":"paragraph","text":"I used to get nervous about meetings because I felt like I always needed to say something smart to impress everyone. When I couldn‚Äôt come up with anything smart to say, I would just try to say¬†anything¬†because otherwise I felt like I didn‚Äôt contribute.","spans":[{"start":193,"end":201,"type":"em"}]},{"type":"paragraph","text":"When I shared this concern with Carolyn, she told me, ‚ÄúIf you have nothing to say, there‚Äôs nothing wrong with just listening.‚Äù She mentioned¬†Halli, our CEO, as an example of someone who mostly listens. Most of our internal meetings with Halli are led by other people, sharing their work and getting feedback. He usually lets others give their opinions first, and makes space for people who are more shy. The only time Halli actually says something is when it‚Äôs absolutely needed, and this give his words a lot more weight.","spans":[{"start":141,"end":146,"type":"hyperlink","data":{"link_type":"Web","url":"http://twitter.com/iamharaldur"}}]},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Some people might say this is because Halli is the CEO, and whatever he says probably feels very absolute, but you can also see something very similar with our producer¬†Kyle. When Kyle holds a meeting, you might not really notice him because he‚Äôs listening most of the time. When he talks, it‚Äôs to give someone else a chance to speak, or to help us ask/answer the right questions. Meetings just don‚Äôt run as well without him. Just by watching him, I‚Äôve learned that¬†you can be an incredibly valuable presence when you speak to move the discussion forward, rather than saying an opinion for the sake of having one.","spans":[{"start":169,"end":173,"type":"hyperlink","data":{"link_type":"Web","url":"https://www.linkedin.com/in/kgcaruso"}}]},{"type":"heading3","text":"3. Chill¬†out.","spans":[]}]}},{"slice_type":"image","slice_label":null,"items":[{}],"primary":{"image":{"dimensions":{"width":480,"height":264},"alt":null,"copyright":null,"url":"https://ueno-starter-kit-universally-test.cdn.prismic.io/ueno-starter-kit-universally-test%2F4e5937bf-2154-4371-b7af-96fbfd1433b5_s3.gif","dfds":{"dimensions":{"width":500,"height":500},"alt":null,"copyright":null,"url":"https://ueno-starter-kit-universally-test.cdn.prismic.io/ueno-starter-kit-universally-test%2F4e5937bf-2154-4371-b7af-96fbfd1433b5_s3.gif"}},"caption":[{"type":"paragraph","text":"It me.","spans":[]}]}},{"slice_type":"text","slice_label":null,"items":[{}],"primary":{"text":[{"type":"paragraph","text":"Over the past year, I‚Äôve improved a lot at the craft of design, but my biggest growth as a designer‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand as a person‚Ää‚Äî‚Äähas been learning to relax and not stress out so much.","spans":[]},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Last year, I was the most anxious, paranoid person you could ever find on the planet. On my first business trip, I missed the flight back to San Francisco, and I honestly thought I‚Äôd never be able to get home. Classic overdramatic Steph.","spans":[]},{"type":"paragraph","text":"I called Carolyn from the airport on the verge of tears. She said something that I now remind myself of every day:","spans":[]}]}},{"slice_type":"quote","slice_label":null,"items":[{}],"primary":{"quote":[{"type":"paragraph","text":"‚ÄúIf there‚Äôs nothing you can do about it, don‚Äôt worry about¬†it.‚Äù","spans":[]}]}},{"slice_type":"text","slice_label":null,"items":[{}],"primary":{"text":[{"type":"paragraph","text":"She told me to go get some breakfast and chill in the airport for a while. And, when I finally feel okay, I can go to ask the people at the airline counter to take the next flight. She was right. I calmed down, made it back to SF, and now I always get to the airport two hours early.","spans":[]},{"type":"paragraph","text":"Of course, there are the (many) times I‚Äôm anxious about situations I¬†do¬†have control over. When something is ambiguous and daunting, it‚Äôs easy to get paralyzed by fear.¬†Where do I start? What if that‚Äôs wrong? What if I mess up?","spans":[{"start":69,"end":71,"type":"em"},{"start":169,"end":227,"type":"em"}]},{"type":"paragraph","text":"I‚Äôve messed up at work plenty of times, but have also seen how my anxiety gets in the way before anything even starts. After a year of diving into unknowns and coming out just fine, I‚Äôve learned to give myself some credit and think to myself that there‚Äôs no reason why I can‚Äôt do something. And even if it goes wrong, it‚Äôs not the end of the world. We‚Äôll figure it out, together.","spans":[]}]}}],"meta_title":[],"meta_description":[],"meta_image":{}}
